newsitem.title: UK: Three hurt in N.Irish street clashes.
newsitem.headline: Three hurt in N.Irish street clashes.

text.p: Three people were hurt, one of them seriously, in overnight street clashes in two Northern Ireland towns, British security sources said on Sunday.
One of two men who received head injuries in fighting between Protestants and Catholics in Portadown was described as "serious but stable" in a Belfast hospital.
A boy of 13 was receiving hospital treatment for a wound near his eye that people in Lurgan said had been caused by a plastic bullet fired by a British soldier.
Police said patrolling troops had been attacked by a crowd throwing stones and other missiles.

Police restored order in neighbouring Portadown after a clash between pro-British Protestants and pro-Irish Catholics. The town was the scene of bitter sectarian strife last year that spread to other areas.

Tension has risen in the British province in recent months because of violence by Irish Republican Army guerrillas, and the onset of a period of Protestant marches which Catholics say inflame sectarian passions.
Police said on Sunday that they had issued an order banning a march by the Protestant Orange Order scheduled later in the day from entering a Catholic stronghold.
The Orange Order supports rule from London, which is opposed by Catholics who want Northern Ireland merged with neighbouring Ireland.
